results.title: The Film
results.creator_credit: Sandra Ostertag, CBS, Coast Community Colleges, Holt, Rinehart and Winston and KOCE-TV (Television station : Huntington Beach, Calif.)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 7 of Series “The Photographic vision”.
Explores the factors to be considered when selecting film for a specific photographic situation. Commercial photographer, Jim Wood, discusses the process of choosing the most appropriate film for an assignment. Explains how the speed of a film determines its graininess, contrast, suitability for action shots, and sensitivity to various lighting conditions.

results.title: The Filleting machine
results.brief_description: A dramatised film which looks at the conflict of values between husband and wife in a working class family. The wife’s ambition for her children are ridiculed by the husband. Written by Tom Hadaway, camera by Peter Roberts and Peter Woodhouse.

results.title: The Fighting lady: a drama of the Pacific
results.creator_credit: Louis de Rochemont Associates and Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation
results.brief_description: Incredible and rare footage of World War Two combat shot by U.S. combat men. An authentic record, starting in January 1943 - planes join an aircraft carrier and proceed to action in the pacific; Marcus Island, August 1943 - footage of Japanese Kamikaze pilots dive bombing U.S. planes at the carrier.

results.title: The Fibre web
results.creator_credit: Henry Cooper, Alan Harper and Campbell Harper Films
results.brief_description: Shows the manufacture of high-quality paper in Scotland, and its uses throughout the world. Today, the uses of paper extend beyond visible applications for books, or maps, labels, or cheques, to become the insulators for telephone cables, giant transformers or computers. Narrated by Kenneth Horne.

results.title: The Fenlands
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Regional Geography”.
The Fenlands situated in Eastern England are one of the flattest regions of Britain. The Fenland landscape is almost wholly manmade, being the result of draining the land, to make it available for agriculture. The danger of flooding is ever present, and in 1947 a disastrous flood occurred. In an attempt to overcome the problem, an extensive sluice system has been devised.

results.title: The Feathers of peace [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Barry Barclay, Ruth Panapa and He Taonga Films
results.brief_description: Written and directed by Barry Barclay, “Feathers of peace” documents the destruction, by both Maori and European invaders, of the Moriori people, the original inhabitants of the Chatham Islands which lie 870 km east of mainland New Zealand. The tragic history unfolds in 4 sections using black and white reconstructed ‘archival’ footage of poor visual and aural quality, interviews, drawings, stills and musical interludes with voice overs. Employing an innovative and sometimes confusing style, the documentary follows the decline of the peaceful Moriori from the initial minor cultural misunderstandings that take place when the first English ship arrives, to their full-scale enslavement and massacre by the Maori.

results.title: The Fate of the universe
results.creator_credit: David P. Stone and Coastal Community Colleges
results.brief_description:
Episode number 18 of Series “Universe: the infinite frontier: an introductory astronomy telecourse”.
Philosophers and scientists have pondered not only our beginning, but also our end. Will the universe end in “fire or ice”? As the universe expands, galaxies move away from each other. If this happens infinitely, eventually there would be an expanse of dark and little or no light. The forces of gravity however also operate, eventually pulling galaxies closer together. The key to the fate of the universe lies in the study of Dark Matter, the seemingly empty space between bright objects. Astronomers put forward many theories about the composition and purpose of the Dark Matter. Discusses the concepts of the Closed Universe and the Open Universe.

results.title: The Fat film
results.brief_description: This film demonstrates in a humorous manner the social difficulties encountered by an individual undertaking a weight reduction plan. It presents the story of Kate, her resolve to begin a diet, her failure to maintain it, and her resolution to try again. Related issues include peer pressure, the social significance of food, stereotyping, public/media image of the body ideal.

results.title: The Fast Track
results.creator_credit: Stephen Jones, Ken Chown, ABC-TV (Australia) and Granada International Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Hypothetical (Television Program)”.
The Minister for Enterprise has a pet Bicentennial project: he wants to build the fastest train in the world, to service marginal electorates on its run from Sydney to Canberra. Businessmen and lobbyists share his enthusiasm for the supertrain but his Department head has reservations which the Press and the Parliamentary Opposition are keen to exploit! Moderator: Geoffrey Robertson.
